comment._content: Very Nice Portrait of a Handsome & Honorable Young Man.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Hmmm, I'm not sure what to make of this, but I've found an R K Law is mentioned twice in The Times: Nov 21st 1931 -in a list of successful candidates in the Intermediate Examination of the Law Society, an 'R.K Law' is listed as passing the Trust Accounts and Book Keeping Portion Dec 2nd 1933 - in a list headed 'The Law Society announces that the following candidates ... were successful in the Final Examination held on November 6 and 7'. He is listed as 'Law, R. K., BA, LLB Dublin'. Coincidence?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Coincidence? I think not! Would I be right in thinking you're talking about the London as opposed to Irish Times? I think I have access to The Times in work so I'll have a look. Having passed the Bar in Ireland, and if he moved to England would he have had to do more exams?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] ;Yes, London Times. That's what I was thinking, that he'd qualified in Ireland then had to start all over again when he moved to England (for whatever reason)

comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content: A fine image and quite a nice portrait of the man. I see the word honourable used above, Interesting!

comment.author: 57139267@N06
comment._content:
From King's Inns Barristers 1868-2004 by Kenneth Ferguson, 2005:
p.226
"LAW, ROBERT KENNETH (b. 21 June 1906) only s. of Frederick William Law, of Evington, Carlow, Co. Carlow, and Eveleen Edith Dockeray; B.A. (Mod.), LL.B. (T.C.D.)"
p.350
"Hilary 1929
(Tuesday 18th January 1929)
Law, Robert Kenneth"
He was the only one called to the bar that term.

comment.author: 57139267@N06
comment._content: Either the day or date is wrong in the book - must have been Friday 18th January.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pwaldron] Hello Paddy! Lovely to hear from you again, you haven't been around for a while. Thanks for this great information, which I've added to the description above.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
